concepts.title: Asset vs. Liability
concepts.article:
# Assets vs. Liabilities

Understanding the difference between an asset and a liability is the single most important rule in finance.

## The Golden Rule

> **"An asset puts money in your pocket. A liability takes money out of your pocket."** - Robert Kiyosaki

### What is an Asset? ðŸ“ˆ
Anything that has value and can generate income or appreciate over time.

**Examples:**
- **Stocks:** Pay dividends and grow in value
- **Real Estate:** Pays rental income
- **Bonds:** Pay interest
- **Intellectual Property:** Royalties from books/patents

### What is a Liability? ðŸ“‰
Anything that takes money out of your pocket, including expenses and debts.

**Examples:**
- **Car:** Loses value (depreciation) + fuel + insurance
- **Credit Card Debt:** High interest payments
- **Subscription Services:** Monthly cash outflow
- **Personal Loans:** Monthly EMI

## The Rich vs. Poor Mindset

- **The Poor:** Income â†’ Expenses
- **The Middle Class:** Income â†’ Buy Liabilities (thinking they are assets, like a big house) â†’ Expenses
- **The Rich:** Income â†’ Buy Assets â†’ Assets generate more Income

## Real-World Analogy

Think of your finances like a **bucket**.
- **Assets** are faucets pouring water (money) IN.
- **Liabilities** are holes letting water (money) leak OUT.

To fill the bucket, you can either turn up the faucets (buy assets) or patch the leaks (reduce liabilities). Doing both is the fastest way to wealth!

concepts.title: Net Worth
concepts.article:
# Net Worth: Your Financial Scorecard

Your net worth is the most accurate measure of your financial health. It's not about how much you earn, but how much you keep.

## The Formula

```
Net Worth = Total Assets - Total Liabilities
```

### Step 1: Add up your Assets ðŸ’°
- Cash in bank
- Investments (Stocks, Mutual Funds)
- Market value of your home/car
- Gold/Jewelry

### Step 2: Add up your Liabilities ðŸ’¸
- Student loans
- Credit card debt
- Home loans (Mortgage)
- Car loans

### Step 3: Subtract
If you have â‚¹50 Lakh in assets and â‚¹30 Lakh in debt, your **Net Worth is â‚¹20 Lakh**.

## Why it Matters

A high income doesn't mean you are rich. If you earn â‚¹50 Lakh a year but spend â‚¹55 Lakh, your net worth is decreasing! You are technically getting poorer despite the high salary.

> **"It's not what you make, it's what you keep."**

## Goal
Track your net worth every 6 months. It should be trending **upwards**. If it's negative (you owe more than you own), your priority should be debt repayment.

concepts.title: Compound Interest
concepts.article:
# Compound Interest: The 8th Wonder of the World

Compound interest is the cycle of earning "interest on interest". It is the secret weapon of all successful long-term investors.

## How it Works

Imagine you invest **â‚¹10,000** at **10%** interest.

- **Year 1:** You earn â‚¹1,000. Total = â‚¹11,000.
- **Year 2:** You earn 10% on â‚¹11,000 (not just the original â‚¹10k). That's â‚¹1,100! Total = â‚¹12,100.
- **Year 3:** You earn 10% on â‚¹12,100. That's â‚¹1,210!

Over 20-30 years, this snowball effect creates massive wealth.

## The Power of Starting Early â°

**Person A:** Starts investing at age 25, invests â‚¹5,000/month for 10 years, then STOPS.
**Person B:** Starts at age 35, invests â‚¹5,000/month for 25 years.

**Who has more money at age 60?**
Surprisingly, **Person A** often wins! Because their money had 10 extra years to compound.

## The Rule of 72
A shortcut to calculate how long it takes to double your money.

```
Years to Double = 72 / Interest Rate
```

**Example:** At 12% return (typical Nifty 50 return), your money doubles in **72 / 12 = 6 Years**.

## Key Takeaway
You don't need to be a genius to get rich. You just need **Time** and **Consistency**.

concepts.title: What is a Stock?
concepts.article:
# What is a Stock?

A **stock** (also called a **share**) represents a unit of ownership in a company. When you buy a stock, you become a partial owner of that company.

## Key Points

### Ownership
- Each share represents a small piece of the company
- Shareholders have voting rights in company decisions
- You can earn money through dividends and capital appreciation

## Real-World Analogy

Think of a company as a pizza. When the company issues stocks, it's like cutting the pizza into slices. Each slice (stock) represents a portion of the whole pizza (company). If you own 10 slices out of 100, you own 10% of the pizza!

concepts.title: Exchanges (NSE/BSE)
concepts.article:
# Stock Exchanges: NSE & BSE

A **stock exchange** is a marketplace where buyers and sellers trade stocks. Think of it like a farmer's market, but instead of vegetables, people buy and sell pieces of companies!

### NSE (National Stock Exchange)
- Largest in India
- Benchmark Index: **NIFTY 50**

### BSE (Bombay Stock Exchange)
- Oldest in Asia (1875)
- Benchmark Index: **SENSEX**

## How it Works
1. You place an order on your app (Zerodha, Upstox)
2. App sends order to Exchange (NSE/BSE)
3. Exchange finds a seller matching your price
4. Trade executed!

concepts.title: How Prices Move
concepts.article:
# Why Stock Prices Move?

It's all about **Supply and Demand**.

- **Checking Good News?** (Profit up, new product) â†’ More Buyers â†’ Price â¬†ï¸
- **Bad News?** (Scandal, loss) â†’ More Sellers â†’ Price â¬‡ï¸

## Analogy
Imagine only 10 iPhones are available, but 100 people want them. The price goes UP. If there are 1000 iPhones and nobody wants them, the price drops to clear stock.

Stocks work the exact same way!

concepts.title: Trading vs. Investing
concepts.article:
# The Great Debate: Trading vs. Investing

Though both involve buying stocks, they are completely different ball games.

## Investing ðŸŒ³
**Goal:** Build wealth gradually.
**Timeframe:** Years or Decades.
**Analysis:** Fundamental (Company health, profits).
**Mental State:** Calm, patient.
**Analogy:** Planting a mango tree. You water it, wait years, and eventually, it gives fruit for life.

## Trading âš¡
**Goal:** Generate quick income.
**Timeframe:** Minutes, Days, or Months.
**Analysis:** Technical (Charts, patterns).
**Mental State:** Alert, active, stressful.
**Analogy:** Buying mangoes from a wholesaler and selling them at the market for a profit the same day.

| Feature | Investing | Trading |
|---------|-----------|---------|
| **Risk** | Moderate | High |
| **Return** | 12-15% (CAGR) | Potentially Higher (or 0) |
| **Effort** | Passive | Active Job |
| **Focus** | Value of Company | Price of Stock |

concepts.title: Dividends
concepts.article:
# Dividends: Getting Paid to Wait

A **dividend** is a reward paid to shareholders for their investment. It usually implies the company is profitable and has excess cash.

## How it Works
If TCS declares a dividend of â‚¹50/share and you own 100 shares, you get **â‚¹5,000** directly in your bank account.

## Dividend Yield
```
Dividend Yield = (Dividend per share / Stock Price) Ã— 100
```
High dividend yield stocks (like ITC, Coal India) are great for passive income portfolios.

concepts.title: P/E Ratio
concepts.article:
# P/E Ratio (Price-to-Earnings)

The most common metric to check if a stock is cheap or expensive.

**Formula:**
```
Stock Price / Earnings Per Share (EPS)
```

## What it tells you
It tells you how much you are paying for â‚¹1 of the company's earnings.
- **P/E = 20:** You pay â‚¹20 to earn â‚¹1.

### General Rule
- **High P/E:** Investors expect high growth (e.g., Tech stocks).
- **Low P/E:** Company might be undervalued or mature (e.g., Oil/Gas).

**Analogy:** If a shop earns â‚¹1 Lakh/year and is sold for â‚¹20 Lakh, its P/E is 20.

concepts.title: Market Cap
concepts.article:
# Market Capitalization

Shows the total size of the company.

**Formula:**
```
Stock Price Ã— Total Number of Shares
```

## Categories
1. **Large Cap (Top 100):** Safe, stable, moderate returns (Example: Reliance, HDFC).
2. **Mid Cap (Next 150):** Higher growth, higher risk.
3. **Small Cap:** Risky, volatile, but potential for massive returns.

concepts.title: Candlestick Charts
concepts.article:
# Candlestick Charts

The language of traders. A single candle tells you the story of price movement for that period.

## Parts of a Candle
1. **Body:** Difference between Open and Close.
2. **Wicks (Shadows):** The High and Low points.

### Green Candle (Bullish) ðŸŸ¢
- Close price > Open price
- Buyers are in control.

### Red Candle (Bearish) ðŸ”´
- Close price < Open price
- Sellers are in control.

If you see a long green candle, it means buyers dominated the session aggressively.

concepts.title: Support & Resistance
concepts.article:
# Support & Resistance

Imagine a ball bouncing in a room.

### Support (The Floor)
A price level where the stock tends to **stop falling** and bounce back up. Buyers wait here.

### Resistance (The Ceiling)
A price level where the stock struggles to go higher. Sellers wait here.

**Trading Strategy:**
- Buy at Support.
- Sell at Resistance.
- If Resistance is broken, it often becomes a Support!

risk-management.title: Risk Management
risk-management.description: Protect your capital and minimize losses.

concepts.title: Diversification
concepts.article:
# Diversification: Don't Put All Eggs in One Basket

The only "free lunch" in investing. By determining how to divide your money, you reduce risk without necessarily reducing returns.

## Why Diversify?
If you invest 100% in one company and it goes bankrupt, you lose everything. If you invest in 20 companies and one goes bankrupt, you only lose 5%.

### How to Diversify
1. **Across Assets:** Stocks, Gold, Bonds, Real Estate.
2. **Across Sectors:** Banking, IT, Pharma, Auto.
3. **Across Geographies:** India, US Market.

> **"Diversification is protection against ignorance."** - Warren Buffett

concepts.title: Stop Loss
concepts.article:
# Stop Loss: Your Safety Net

A **Stop Loss (SL)** is an automatic order to sell your stock if it falls to a certain price.

## Example
You buy a stock for â‚¹100.
You set a Stop Loss at â‚¹95.

If the market crashes and the stock falls to â‚¹80, your SL triggers at â‚¹95, limiting your loss to just â‚¹5.

### Why use it?
- Prevents emotional holding of losing stocks.
- Protects your capital from market crashes.
- Essential for traders, recommended for investors.
